Robert Watkins wrote:

> Well, there's the one I was learning yesterday: XMLBeans from the Apache 
> project. There's newer versions of Weblogic (the old ones had the 
> kitchen-sink JAR from hell). The xml-apis.jar and xercesImpl.jar from 
> the Xerces project. The way Ant 1.6 has the optional jars split up. 
> Jaxen. Every JDBC driver I've ever used. Hibernate.

OK. Two of those I know intimately (Xerces and Jaxen) and one partially 
(Ant). The two I know intimately don't behave as you claim. The 
distinction between xercesImpl.jar and xml-apis.jar is not between 
public and published. It is between standard, cross-parser APIs and 
Xerces specific APIs. xercesImpl.jar contains both external code with 
stable APIs and internal code whose API may change.

Jaxen is not divided at all. I've actually been meaning to divide the 
Jaxen single JAR archive for awhile now, but along very different lines. 
Perhaps an older version of Jaxen split off Saxpath and Jaxen itself 
into two JARs, (both of which were public and published) but they are 
now distributed as a single JAR containing all the Jaxen classes. There 
are definitely too many public classes in Jaxen , and I'd like to make 
many of them non-public. However, legacy issues keep me from pulling the 
trigger.

Ant I'm not as familiar with at the code level, but my impression is 
that the distribution in many jar files has everything to do with the 
plugin architecture and little-to-nothing to do with distinguishing 
between public and published.

The others you mention, I'll just have to take your word on. However, 
just because a project distributes multiple jar archives, even ones as 
suggestively named as foo-apis.jar and fooImpl.jar, does not prove that 
one contains published APIs and the other does not. Xerces is a clear 
counterexample to this assumption.

> I don't see it as the duty of an API designer to protect people who 
> deliberately go out of their way to inflict pain and suffering on 
> themselves. Making a clear distinction to the client programmer is all 
> that's called for.

I do, however, see it as the duty of the API designer to not design an 
API in such a way that people using it are likely to choose the most 
pain-free, correct mode of operation. In a good API the right thing 
should be obvious and easy. The wrong thing should be difficult to 
impossible. The API should be designed in such a way that people have to 
go out of their way to inflict pain and suffering on themselves. It 
should be designed such that they don't inflict pain and suffering by 
accident. Too many APIs make inflicting pain and suffering just as easy 
or easier as a painfree experience. That's just wrong.

The argument here reminds me of the old saw that it's the user's 
responsibility to read the manual, and that any poorly designed 
interface that's virtually certain to confuse and be misused is OK, as 
long as it's documented in 10-point type on p. 345 of a telephone book 
sized manual.  It wasn't true for user interfaces 20 years ago, and it 
isn't true for programming interfaces today. Good interfaces, be they 
GUIs or APIs, follow the fundamental principles of human computer 
interaction. Good interfaces are natural, intuitive, and easy to use. 
Bad ones aren't, documentation or no.
